Hidden Gems

How often do you see a white teacher transform a class full of recalcitrant students from different races and backgrounds to a class full of great individuals? That is what happened in the movie Freedom Writers. Erin Gruwell is the white teacher and the students are class 203 of Woodrow Wilson High School. At the beginning, class 203 is just a bunch of people who hate learning and have no future. However, it all changes since the presence of Erin Gruwell. She approaches this unteachable class and starts to develop their emotional intelligence. From students who like to neglect the lesson, refuse listening to the teacher, and do not care about each other, they start to show changes in their learning skill. But at the start of the movie, the students, notably Marcus and Eva show no enthusiasm nor compassion in anything and anyone. Nevertheless, the first empathy is shown when the students come to visit the Holocaust Museum. They are stunned by how they have so much better situation than the Holocaust survivors. From that moment, Marcus and Eva start to develop their empathy skill. There is a scene where a guy named Miguel comes up to the middle of the class and starts to read his journal. Miguel shares his struggle about his early life and how he is now happy that he has found a new home, class 203. And then, Marcus, a guy who seems very quiet and tough, approaches him and gives him his empathy. He shakes his hand, hugs him, and even sheds tears, showing that he empathizes for Miguel.. That scene warms me and I feel empathy for Miguel as well. A similar situation of empathy is also being displayed by Eva when she chooses to defend the truth by telling the court that Paco, her boyfriend is the one who killed the guy in the store instead of the black guy. By saying the truth, she betrays her own people but she does the right and that shows how she has changed and developed her empathy. According to Paul Wong’s article about empathy he notes that “… individuals are more likely to be empathic to others, when they have experienced many hardships and are well acquainted with sorrows and sufferings.” This is what I see in the movie, Marcus and Eva realize that they all came from the same background; that they must fight for their lives, dignity, and existence. Thus, both Marcus and Eva develop what Wong would call the “experiential empathy” which is a type of empathy that is developed when one has experienced other’s difficulties.
